ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:48): Some of the definitions are more generic, but if the goal was for RFC2119 to apply to non-implementations requirements too then presumably the whole thing would have been written in a more generic way
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:48): though perhaps it doesn't really matter what the original intent was
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:49): It matters if people start trying to selectively interpret the intent of the original phrasing

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:50): FWIW I agree with ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c to the extent that RFC 2119 is clearly not intended to deal with authoring requirments when the client is liberal
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:50): (or perhaps in general)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:50): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: it is a mistake for them to do that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:50): I don't think this is a big problem except insofaras people try to spac lawyer as if it was

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:50): I think the use of must/should/etc for authoring requirements is useful and sensible and good, but specs should be clear that it's a wilful violation of RFC2119
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:51): so that people can't validly claim that the spec is silently inconsistent with the other specs it normatively references

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:53): would prefer people just stopped that because it is obviously a trivial inconsistency, hasn't been a problem for other specs, and only matters to spec lawyers anyway
